course.subject: COMP
course.name: Data Mining
course.description: This course will provide an introduction to concepts and techniques in the field of data mining. Materials include an introduction to data warehousing and OLAP, data preprocessing and the techniques used to explore the large quantities of data for the discovery of predictive models and knowledge. The course will include techniques such as nearest neighbor, decision tress, neural networks, Bayesian networks and Naive Bayes, rule-based methods, association analysis and clustering, as well as social networks and data mining applications in business and finance applications, and other emerging data mining subareas. Students learn the materials by attending lectures and implementing and applying different data analysis and mining techniques to large datasets throughout the semester.
course.prerequisites: ELEC 2600 OR IEDA 2510 (prior to 2018-19) OR IEDA 2520 OR IEDA 2540 OR ISOM 2500 OR LIFS 3150 OR MATH 2411 OR MATH 2421 OR MATH 2431
course.exclusions: COMP 4211, ISOM 3360

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Complete disconnect between lectures and assignments
reviews.comment_content:
An "introductory" course to data mining and machine learning. Just like any other "introductory" courses, if you have no prior knowledge you'll surely be fucked up. If you're RMBI students or you aren't proficient in Python, DROP THIS COURSE IMMEDIATELY and take ISOM3360 instead.

Key topics include a number of algorithms for frequent pattern mining, classification, clustering, outlier detection, collaborative filtering, etc.

0️⃣ Introduction to Data Mining
1️⃣ Getting to know your data
2️⃣ Data Preprocessing
3️⃣ Frequent Pattern Mining
      🔶 Apriori
      🔶 FP-growth
      🔶 Discretize Continuous Variables
      🔶 Generalized Sequential Pattern (GSP)
4️⃣ Classification
      🔶 K-nearest Neighbor (KNN)
      🔶 Decision Tree Induction
      🔶 Naive Bayes Classifier
      🔶 Bayesian Belief Network
      🔶 Confusion Matrix
      🔶 Ensemble Methods
      🔶 Neural Network
      🔶 Support Vector Machines (SVM)
5️⃣ Clustering
      🔶 K-means Clustering
      🔶 K-medoids Clustering
            PAM
      🔶 Hierarchical Clustering
      🔶 Density-based Clustering
            DBSCAN
      🔶 Fuzzy Clustering
            Fuzzy EM
      🔶 Probabilistic Model-based Clustering
            Univariate Gaussian Mixture Model
      🔶 Subspace Clustering
            Dense Unit-based and Entropy-based Methods
6️⃣ Outlier Analysis
      🔶 Statistical Approaches
      🔶 Nested Loop Algorithm
      🔶 Cell-based Algorithm
      🔶 Local Outlier Factor (LOF)
7️⃣ Collaborative Filtering
8️⃣ Social Media
      🔶 Edge Betweenness
      🔶 K-L
9️⃣ OLAP and Data Cube
      🔶 OLAP Operations
      🔶 Data Warehouse: Materialize View
            Greedy Algorithm
🔟 Web Mining
      🔶 PageRank
      🔶 Hypertext-Induced Topic Search (HITS)

Note that this course is mainly on theory and is grossly unrelated to the assignments and the project. Nobody ever teaches how to code the algorithm and how to use the Python packages. When it comes to the assignments and the project, we all end up in learning all by ourselves.

I sincerely wish that we were taught how to import, manipulate, and visualize data using the NumPy, pandas, matplotlib and scikit-learn packages. Knowing how to do data mining by hand doesn't help sh!t at all.
reviews.comment_teaching:
At first Prof CHEN's teaching seemed not bad at all. But I later discovered that he had a notorious habit of just skimming through all these algorithms and casually skipping a lot of the details, and he expected all of us to understand all of them as if we were all genii? I knew there were a lot of genii in the class, but I was deffo not one of them. Thus I instead learned by going over YouTube videos on data mining, and I found this 100x more effective than attending his lectures.

Okay. Just another self-learning course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad. The TAs have been quite lenient in marking our assignments and projects. But as most of us score high in the assignments and the projects, exams become the determining factor of our grade.

✏️ Midterm
Mean = 37/60

✏️ Final
Mean = 75/100, SD = 15

I got 36/60 in the midterm, 78/100 in the final, 98/100 in the project and averaged around 90 in the 3 assignments. Overall I got around 82.7% and this translated into a B+.

As a tip, don't be in despair when your codes do not run. I encountered quite a few times the situation when the codes in my assignments and project did not run at all, but I still managed to secure 90-ish by outlining the logic in my comments, explaining how I approached the problem, writing some partial codes, and most importantly, submitting PUNCTUALLY. Don't submit late even if you cannot finish the assignments. You might be surprised at how many marks you've secured by submitting partial codes with some explanation in the code and the report. Another thing is that if you've used Python packages outside of those suggested by the TAs (which is totally fine), there is no way the TAs could verify whether your codes could actually run or not.
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely heavy workload. Prof Chen seems to have very high expectation on us.

💻 20% Assignments
💻 30% Project
✏️ 20% Midterm
✏️ 30% Final

There are a total of 3 assignments in Python. All of them require the use of Anaconda, a distribution of Python designed for the purpose of data mining. The assignments are deffo not easy and we are required to spend some time to self-explore what the heck the tasks are and how to use the scikit-learn packages. Again, it's about the ability to self-learn.

And then the fucking project! It was my worst nightmare ever. The project was a dropout prediction task extracted from the professional KDD-cup competition. We were allowed to form groups of up to 3 groupmates, but even with 3 people we still ate sh!t in the project. The project required us to do the data preprocessing (which spent us about 80% of our time) including loading and manipulating the data into a data structure we needed, feature engineering with discretization, data aggregation and transformation, selecting 3 classifiers for prediction, applying cross-validation for these classifiers, ensembling the classifiers and evaluating the classifiers with confusion matrices. This is the most demanding project I've ever met and you can imagine all my groupmate staying in front of our PCs days and nights coding and debugging and coding and debugging... An excellent opportunity to get hands-on experience of how it feels in the hell.

As for the exams they're basically concept-based written papers covering various algorithms taught in class. No codes. Just data mining by hands, with a definitely insufficient amount of time. They were among the sh!ttiest papers ever as they differentiated us based on our speed instead of our understanding of the concepts.

reviews.author: Andrio
reviews.comment_content:
Important concepts of data mining and big data are covered well. Good introductory course if you are curious in big data (how come diapers and beers are often bought together on a supermarket?) or looking to be a data scientist like me.
Assignments cover both written and programming (1st assignment in c++ while 2nd one in java or c++). Then midterm and final as usual.
The course was more on understanding the concepts than mathematics which I was expecting. You would find more questions using mathematics on the assignments while the exams would have more conceptual questions (like predicting how the result would look like given this input and this technique then explaining why).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures are okay. Sometimes he tries to make jokes and when I get it I laugh (when I don't get it I just smile). But when he goes really technical, it could be rather boring. Sometimes he tries to show live demos of the materials over websites but mostly fails because the demo is using Java Applet. The lecture desktop does not allow it to run.
One time he was demoing a concept by googling his name. Somehow he stumbled to a website containing reviews about his teachings. He was surprised and spent a minute reading the review in front of the class. That was the best lecture session of this course in my opinion.
reviews.comment_grading: Seems the course is quite generous in putting the A range. Just try to keep your grades on almost 1 SD and above mean and you should be guaranteed A range I guess.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignment workload is reasonable (3 assignments). Usually not taking too much time compared to other COMP4xxx courses.
If your programming skills aren't that good or you just don't like programming, it might take more time for you to do the programming assignment. Usually you need to implement one of the machine learning techniques (the easy ones). You should also make some documentation about the program (comments on code, how to run, etc.).

reviews.author: 上海灘龍虎鬥
reviews.title: Please dont trust those out-dated comment about him
reviews.comment_content:
-Data Preprocessing
data summarization, cleaning, integration, transformation, reduction and discretization

-Classification and Regression
decision trees, neural networks, Bayesian classification, rule-based classification, and various regression methods

-Cluster Analysis
partitioning, hierarchical and density-based clustering algorithms, as well as outlier detection techniques

-Association Analysis
popular frequent itemset mining algorithms
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Kwok focus on the algorithm on data mining, which is quite different from what I expect he will teach in the course. In fact, he only talks about the algorithm, and in his lectures he never talk about any coding which is related to data mining. However, in the assignment and project later, require advanced techniques which make me suffer when doing the assignments and projects. Although TA will talk about coding in tutorial section, it is not sufficient because there is just one hour per week and they just talked about very easy codes. when it come to assignments and projects, it still take tons of time for me to google and find out what code is useful.

Unlike other comp course, it does not have lab session. I would prefer there is one though the workload will be more.  The reason is lab session can help consolidate and make application what we learnt in the lecture and give more ideas when it comes to assignment and projects.
reviews.comment_grading:
Three assignments: 30%
Mini Project: 20%
Group Project: 40%
Turn on webcam: 10%
Overall I got above mean and I got a B-.
Utterly bad Grading
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is huge. As mentioned above, you need to find out what code is useful in your assignment and projects. You will not know what code you can use if you just attend the lecture even the tutorials. Project arrangement is also very bad. Group formation deadline is 30/11 this semester. He did not take into account that many students are having final in early to mid December. Assignment 3 is also due in mid December as well. As a result, in December, I needed to revise for my finals, do assignment 3 and group project which is a disaster. It is not understandable that why he did not set the deadline earlier and give students more time to do the project.

reviews.author: loveust
reviews.title: Super heavy workload
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
·         The Data Mining Process
·         Preprocessing and Model Evaluation
·         Classification
·         Clustering
·         Association Studies
·         Text and Web Mining
·         Social Networks
·         Other Applications
reviews.comment_teaching: Lei Chen teaches in a fast pace, and just read from the powerpoint. Basically, this course is learnt by yourself via Youtube. Moreover, the assignment are all based on coding while lecture and tutorial are only based on concept.
reviews.comment_workload:
Supreme and non sense workload
Assignment all about python code which not mentioned in the course description and not been taught.

reviews.author: MeiLing:)
reviews.title: Bad Teaching but good grade
reviews.comment_content: The content includes different techniques of machine learning e.g. classification, clustering, decision tree, etc. Quite useful and funny if you are interested in machine learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: This teacher don't know how to teach, there are less than 20 students will attend his lecture. He could not project his voice, and his lecture is very boring.
reviews.comment_grading: Super good grading, me and most of my friends got an A range from this course. My midterm was below mean but my final was above mean for 4-5 marks then I got an A-
reviews.comment_workload: The assignments are very tough. There are total of 3 assignments, with 2-3 questions each, but we are always required to write a "small" program using C++/python/Java/VBA, which is actually a tough work. Better to find some people who are good at coding to study with you.

reviews.author: Harry Lai
reviews.title: Really Depends on Lecturer
reviews.comment_content:
The content is not the big problem of this course as it has already covered the necessary knowledge about data mining. However, the notes did not offered detailed example for the data mining algorithm and calculations which requires students to keep learning by themselves.

Topics:
Data Preprocessing
Classification
Decision Tree
Bayesian Classification
Nearest-Neighbor Classification
Rule-Based Classification
Neural Networks
Support Vector Machines
Ensemble Methods
Clustering
k-means clustering
Hierarchical Clustering
Density-Based Clustering
Finite Mixture Model
Association Analysis
Apriori Algorithm
FP-Growth Algorithm
Social Network Mining
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor did not explain anything during the lecture class by just reading the lecture notes word by word. I felt very disappointing with his attitude during teaching. He also change the grading rubrics suddenly before the examination and change back to original again by just less than 24 hours which is very frustrated for me.
The tutorial session is much more useful then the lecture session and the instructor is helpful.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is adequate as it consisted of 3 assignments with mid-term and final examination. The assignments contain programming question and some calculation question.

reviews.author: Hopper
reviews.title: Don't believe the previous comment the whole course is restructured
reviews.comment_content:
Course information

Teaching Assistants

Lifeng SHEN (office hour: Fri, 1:30-3pm)
Lawrence CHAN (office hour: Wed, 3:30-5pm)

Assignments

assignment 1

assignment 2
project (data)
Dec22, 11:59pm: Deadline to upload the report/code/model to Canvas
Dec23: Project presentations
Each group will have 15min (including Q&A). The presentation schedule is here. If you have any change requests, please email (together with strong reasons) to the TA.
Attendance of all the group presentations is compulsory (and you have to switch on the webcam). Failure to do so will lead to a penalty of 10% on the project.
If you run out of time, focus the presentation on your additional analysis.
Dec23, 11:59pm: Each group should upload to Canvas the slides used during the presentation
Dec23, 11:59pm: Each student should upload the following to Canvas
your self-evaluation with (a) a brief description of your contribution in the r eport and presentation; (b) your percentage contribution to the whole project;
evaluation of the percentage contribution of each individual members in the group to the whole project (you only need to give the TA a number, no description is needed).
peer-evaluation for all the other groups. The form is here.
assignment 3
reviews.comment_teaching: Well, for the teaching remember to open your camera and just listen him to read the ppt. nothing special
reviews.comment_grading:
Worst.
All above mean B
No idea what happened.
probably others grade are great?
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is appropriate but all the content are irrelevant.

reviews.author: wcleeae
reviews.comment_content: The content is mainly practical machine learning. The course mainly focuses on applying machine learning techniques using python and several of its libraries. Course content includes classification, frequent item mining, social media mining, web mining, etc. This course focuses on the practical aspect of machine learning unlike the machine learning course in HKUST, which focuses more on the theoretical aspect of machine learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: The course will be difficult to understand as the slides are structured very inefficiently. He covers the content in a random order so the order of the lecture slides won't matter much. His english is ok but hard to understand some parts. Searching online and reading articles about the topic helped me a ton when I didn't understand class lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was very good considering the percentage I got.

Midterm 42/60, mean 37
Final 78/100, mean 75
Grade: A-

The projects and assignments are each 30% and 20%, and midterm is 20% and final is 30%. Although the content is difficult and project is very demanding, the grades turned out to be good.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload will be very tough as there are 3 big assignments as well as a big project that is announced early on. As the course covers a lot of content, studying for the exams will also be rough. The assignments are doable but require lots of checking and waiting as running the machine learning code will often take hours to complete. The group project also requires a lot of effort as the professor expects us to use most of the content covered in the course without much help from the tutors. A lot of individual research on the web is required.

reviews.author: Luoshu
reviews.title: Data mining
reviews.comment_content: The content of the course is not bad. This course mainly focuses on data mining. To be more specific, it is about frequent item mining, classification methods, clustering methods, collaborative filter, social media mining and web mining. If you fully understand the concept of the course, you will definitely have a clear understanding on data mining and machine learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have to say Prof. Chen's teaching is awful. Initially, I think that he is a good instructor. However, after going through half of the semester, I am totally confused about the concepts and I cannot learn any essential information from the lecture. At the same time, the lectures and tutorials are not related to the course assignment and project AT ALL. Especially in November, he just went through the lecture slides in a extremely fast pace. From my point of view, this course can just be completed by self-learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair. In terms of my self, the statistics are listed as below:

Midterm 52/60, mean 37
Final 70/100, mean 75

All the remaining parts (the project and assignments) are fully marks. In terms of each component, it is assignment 20%, midterm 20%, project 30%, final 30%.

Final grade is B+. Although I have scored below mean in the final exam, I can still get a B+. I can say the grading is not bad.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very significant workload. The project and assignments all requires significant time to complete.

Since this is a "machine learning" course, the running time of the computer program takes extremely long, which means that you have to wait for a really long time to determine whether your code yields the right result. At the same time, there is no skeleton code for all the assignments and project, which means that you have to start from the very beginning. Moreover, the lectures and tutorials is not related to the assignment which means that probably you have to learn all these things from Google.

reviews.author: gary_ho122
reviews.title: Bad course compare to other comp course
reviews.comment_content: The content is mostly about Data Mining Process and Classification. However, these are some old method of the data analysis in nowadays. Not much updated package and library will be teach.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fine. However, the instructor had some bad english and hard to hear what he said. It is quite hard to focus in class.This teacher don't know how to teach and many people skip the class.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is bad because there is a lot of comp student in this course. My midterm was below mean and my final was below mean for 10 marks only then I got an B. A lot of cse student will use this course to full fill the requirement of minor in big data. I think comp4211 will be better instead of comp 4331.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is hard for business student and rmbi student. It require a lot of knowledge of programming in Java and python. If you is a business student or not good at programming. I suggest you should better choose other comp course or business course to full fill the requirement.

reviews.author: Sungsu
reviews.comment_content:
Deals with basic concepts of data mining:
- Decision Trees, Information Gain, Gain Ratio,
- SVM, Artificial Neural Network
- ...

This course is exclusive with COMP4212 Machine Learning course and course materials overlap but this course is less focused on math. It is also a required course for RMBI and so less programming as well.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is an engaging professor and he tries to make sure that you understand the concept before moving on. Classes can be slow if no one answers his questions.
He is quite good at explaining concepts in easy terms and examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty generous and he is quite flexible in discussing with us the exam coverage and assignments.

The assignments are mostly pencil and paper problems, with one question related to programming. But even for programming it is more focused on applying the concepts you've learned in class so it 's not too difficult and as long as you know how to program in Java or C++ it's pretty easy.
reviews.comment_workload:
As this course is more focused on concepts it is important that you need to understand them well. The exam questions are designed so that you need to think more rather than recalling the concepts you've memorized.
The exams are closed book so you still need to memorize some basic formula for calculating something, but that is minimal.

reviews.author: 想當年
reviews.title: 【Mixed-mode semester during COVID-19】face-to-face，course grading變返正常？
reviews.comment_content: 整個course無乜嘢背，主要係明白steps/algorithms。由於這個course比較簡單，上堂明到就得，不需花太多時間溫習。（其實是沒有什麼好溫習，因為沒有past paper或practice exercise。）
reviews.comment_teaching:
prof. james kwok:
他教得很慢，但教得很清晰。他上堂喜歡 interact with students，他亦喜歡用生活例子做類比，所以都容易明，上他堂都不會太悶。
________________________________________

TA: Mr. Zheng, Yimin + Mr. Jiang, Weisen + Mr. Yu, Runsheng
他們好helpful，覆email多數都好快！
改assignment方面，每個mistakes扣2分，所以個個都至少90幾分。
reviews.comment_grading:
*************************
Here may be biased.
I admit that I do not have enough statistics to judge whether it is really a good grade semester. If you have more information, feel free to comment below.
*************************

Statistics:
No statistics are officially released. Statistics can be seen in canvas in the beginning. It was disabled later. (i.e., we can't see the statistics.)
I remember the mean of the first 2 assignments are both higher than 99% (and no one gets below 94%), and the mean of the midterm is higher than 96%.
________________________________________

考final exam前，估計mean54/55（請看上面statistics），咁即係 final 一試定生死啦！同埋我都有睇 prof.郭天佑 以前的 review (including https://ust.space/review/COMP4211) ，加上見d人咁勁，真心超驚爛grade。
考緊final exam心諗，慘啦，好多題目都唔係好肯定，會唔會below mean㗎。結果⋯超好彩，估唔到自己攞到這個分數。
我當時諗，應該有A range啦，結果⋯一收到grade，完全喜出望外。
________________________________________

For me:
Assignment(30%) 298/300
Midterm(25%) 100/100
Final Exam(45%) 95.5/100

overall = 97.775%
grade = A+
reviews.comment_workload:
COMP courses而言好輕。得3份assignment（絕對唔係COMP2011/2012 programming assignment的難度/長度），prof 話expect我們4-5小時搞掂1份assignment，我無計過，不過感覺合理。
Assignment主要參考吓tutorial的 python code，如果你熟python，可能會更快完成assignment。（小弟係唔識python嘅！)
